all_paragraphs: In this part of the series ‘The NLP Project’, we will understand the various preprocessing steps that must be applied before doing any type of text analytics, such as applying machine learning to text, constructing language models, chatbots, sentiment analysis systems, etc. These steps are used in almost all applications that work with textual data.

To build any machine learning model, one needs to provide it with features/attributes that the algorithm can take in and build the model. But, a generic text does not have any pre-existing features, it is just a combination of words, letters, sentences, etc.
Therefore, to extract features out of a text, we need tokenization.
Tokenization is a technique to break the given text into smaller parts such as characters, words, sentences, or even paragraphs depending on the application you’re working on.

Now, if you use word tokenizer, you would get every word as a feature to be used in model building. Thus, you will get a lot of redundant features such as ‘get’ and ‘getting’, ‘goes’ and ‘going’, ‘see’ and ‘seeing’ and along with a lot of other duplicate features. They are certainly not duplicates, but they are unnecessary in the sense that they do not give you additional information about the message.

Therefore, separating the two hinders the performance of the machine learning algorithm because it is unnecessary information. Also, this repetition increases the number of features so that the classification can face the ‘curse of dimensionality’. To overcome this problem, we have two methods, Stemming and Lemmatization.

Stemming is a rule-based technique that just chops off the suffix of a word to get its root form, which is called the ‘stem’. For example, if you use a stemmer to stem the words of the string — “The driver is racing in his boss’ car”, the words ‘driver’ and ‘racing’ will be converted to their root form by just chopping off the suffixes ‘er’ and ‘ing’. So, ‘driver’ will be converted to ‘driv’ and ‘racing’ will be converted to ‘rac’.

You might think that the root forms (or stems) don’t resemble the root words — ‘drive’ and ‘race’. You don’t have to worry about this because the stemmer will convert all the variants of ‘drive’ and ‘racing’ to those root forms only. So, it will convert ‘drive’, ‘driving’, etc. to ‘driv’, and ‘race’, ‘racer’, etc. to ‘rac’. This gives us satisfactory results in most cases.

Lemmatization is a more sophisticated technology that does not cut the suffix of a word. Instead, it takes the input word and goes through all the variations of dictionary words and searches for its source word. The root word, in this case, is called a lemma. The terms ‘foot’, ‘drive’, ‘’ up ‘’, ‘’ up ‘’ and ‘’ bought ‘’ cannot be reduced to their proper basic form with the stemmer. But the lemmatizer can reduce them to the correct basic form. The most popular lemmatizer is the Wordnet lemmatizer created by a team of researchers at Princeton University. You can read more about it here.
